user.biography: Without our love, the natural world as we know it can–and will–disappear. So, it’s our choice: Love it or lose it. WWF-US

node.text: #EarthHour2021 is tomorrow. Check out this conversation with WWF’s Shauna Mahajan and our #EarthHour meditation guide, @chelsealovesyoga, to discuss mediation, intention, and conservation. Want to learn more about #EarthHour? Click the link in our bio.

node.text: The places on this list need our love now more than ever. Learn why we love them and can’t afford to lose them.

node.title: Nine places we love and need to protect

node.text: Meet Tanner Yess. He's the co-executive director of Groundworks Ohio River Valley (@groundworkorv), an environmental nonprofit that centers on racial environmental justice work. Grassroots organizations like this one and community leaders in Cincinnati, Ohio, have been addressing the climate crisis for years through on-the-ground efforts, policy, and investing in green innovation. Environmental justice plays a key role in tackling this global problem. Learn more by following the link in our bio.

node.title: Centering environmental justice in Cincinnati, Ohio

node.text: More than 166,000 square miles of forest habitat were lost to deforestation between 2004 and 2017. That’s an area roughly the same size as the state of California. “Deforestation is at the root of the most pressing problems currently threatening our planet. It is one of the biggest underlying risk factors for outbreaks of emerging infectious diseases and a primary reason wildfires are more frequent and destructive in critical ecosystems such as the Amazon. It’s also the leading cause of decline in wildlife populations and a major contributor to compounding runaway climate change.” – WWF Senior Vice President for Forests Kerry Cesareo. Click the link in our bio to read our latest report detailing deforestation drivers and responses in a changing world.

node.title: Protecting our breath-giving forests from deforestation

node.text:
Saturday marks the fifth anniversary of the Paris Climate Agreement and a critical turning point for the future of US climate action. WWF’s Grace Lee and Ryan Finnegan talked about what this pivotal moment means for climate action, what happened when 3,900 institutions came together to say “We Are Still In” after the United States announced its intent to withdraw from the agreement in 2017, and what’s next.
 
Check out the link in our bio to learn 5 ways We Are Still In kept the United states in the fight against the climate crisis.

node.title: Five-year Anniversary of the Paris Agreement

node.text:
Inspiring news: The first-ever twins born to habituated gorillas in the Dzanga-Sangha Protected Area are now four years old. Gorilla twins are extremely rare, so the survival of Inguka and Inganda brings hope that it is possible for other gorilla twins to survive in the future. 🦍 🦍Western lowland gorillas are critically endangered and face serious threats from poaching, disease, and habitat loss across Central Africa.

More than two decades ago, WWF launched Dzanga-Sangha’s gorilla habituation program in the Central African Republic. The program—and the tourism income it brought with it—provided local communities with new employment opportunities. Most recently, WWF is working to sustain benefits to the community despite the global travel restrictions caused by COVID-19.

Footage for this video was captured in the fall of 2019. Even before COVID-19, masks were used to protect the habituated gorillas against transmission of diseases from humans.
#conservation #gorillas

node.title: Gorilla twins of Dzanga-Sangha are now four years old

node.text: Meet the shark that doesn’t bite or chew: The whale shark! Although their mouths can stretch to four feet wide, whale shark teeth are so tiny that they can only eat small shrimp, fish, and plankton by using their gills as a suction filter. Whale sharks can process more than 1,585 gallons of water per hour through their gills. Learn more about the world’s largest fish by clicking the link in our bio.

node.text: COVID-19 is the latest zoonotic disease to become a global pandemic. But what does that mean and how can we help stop other infections like it? We need to balance humanity’s relationship with nature. Together we can help prevent pandemics. Click the link in our bio to take action today. #WorldZoonosesDay

node.title: How to help stop future pandemics

node.text: Water plays an important role in the life cycle of saiga antelopes. With less rainfall in the region, and rising temperatures, the species is at risk as small lakes and streams dry up during the summer months driven by a changing climate. That's why WWF's Wildlife Adaptation Innovation Fund (WAIF) went on a mission to find a solution to fix wells, making water readily available to saiga antelope. Follow the link in our bio to learn about this project in the Stepnoi Wildlife Refuge and other projects implemented by WAIF.

node.title: Establishing artificial watering holes for saiga antelope in Russia

node.text: WWF’s Nikhil Advani is here to talk about the climate crisis, the impacts of climate change on wildlife, and the innovative solutions WWF is implementing to help tackle these urgent issues.

node.title: Climate change and species with WWF's Nikhil Advani

node.text: In just seven years, human-driven underwater noise has doubled in some areas of the Arctic. This is an incredibly rapid and concerning increase that puts wildlife in danger. Click the link in our bio to learn more.

node.text:
White tigers are often perceived as an endangered species, but white tiger fur is actually the result of a genetic mutation. In fact, chances of survival of white tigers in the wild are greatly reduced because their fur doesn’t provide any camouflage. Follow the link in our bio to learn the truth about white tigers.

Pictured: A captive white tiger in India.

node.text: Scientists estimate nine out of ten ocean species haven’t been fully identified. This is a deep sea cirrate octopus. What is your favorite ocean species?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by World Wildlife Fund on July 07, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text: Regions around the world are experiencing biodiversity loss at different rates. According to WWF’s 2020 Living Planet report the world has seen an average 68% drop in mammal, bird, fish, reptile, and amphibian populations since 1970. The cause? One major cause is habitat destruction due to unsustainable agriculture or logging. Follow the link in our bio to take a deeper look at how regions around the world have been experiencing biodiversity loss.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by World Wildlife Fund on July 06, 2021. May be an image of animal and nature.

node.text: Poorly planned and placed dams constitute one of the biggest threats to free-flowing rivers and the species that rely on them. The wrong dam in the wrong place can have profound consequences: Dams can alter water flows, block fish migration routes, devastate the habitats of endangered species, and trap nutrient-rich sediment needed to replenish downstream deltas. To preserve the life-sustaining force of long, free-flowing rivers, WWF has been working to stop the construction of poorly placed dams in key geographies around the world, and instead offer alternatives to hydropower energy, such as wind and solar, that can balance the energy portfolio and satisfy demand. Follow the link in our bio to learn more.

node.text: As ocean temperatures rise and habitats change, will whales, sharks, rays, dolphins, turtles, and other sea creatures adapt or go extinct? Find out by following the link in our bio.

node.text:
This story from @willbl was originally posted in World Wildlife magazine. You can read the full magazine article by following the link in our bio.

“The melanistic (black) leopard—or black panther—captivated my imagination when I was a young child in Tanzania, and tales of African black leopard sightings have always held a supernatural allure for me. So, in 2018, when I heard that a black leopard had been spotted in Kenya, I jumped at the chance to get close to the magic.

Following local expertise and fresh tracks, I set several camera traps along a suspected leopard path in the bush. As I waited, the possibility of photographing this elusive creature seemed more and more unlikely. Then one morning, there it was: golden eyes peering out from an inky darkness.

This began a multiyear project to photograph the black leopard against a starry night sky. There were many obstacles: The weather, the moon cycle, and the leopard’s path all had to align; a big spotty male leopard kept chasing off my prized subject; and baboons dismantled my camera traps. But it was all worth it when I finally saw the image I had envisioned.

In my quest, I captured a treasure trove of images now bound in my new book, The Black Leopard. I hope they will encourage people to support the communities and conservation efforts that protect these majestic cats.”

node.text: Industrial thermal emissions are the greenhouse gas emissions released from the industrial process of making everyday items like clothing or the device you’re using to read this right now. These industrial thermal emissions represent one of the greatest climate challenges you’ve likely never heard of, and WWF is working to overcome it. Click the link in our bio to learn more about industrial thermal emissions and WWF’s bold vision to reduce them by 30%.
